Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Novel Prosthetic Arm Control Based on a Low-Dimensional Internal Musculoskeletal Biomechanical (LIMB) Model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Upper limb amputation is a major cause of disability for nearly 160,000 Americans, many of whom could benefit from emergent sophisticated robotic, multifunctional prosthetic arms/hands. In these advanced prostheses, movements are typically controlled by interpreting the user's electromyographic (EMG) signals from residual or reinnervated muscles. State-of-the-art pattern recognition (PR) has been the most promising EMG control interface for multifunctional artificial arms. However, EMG PR-based control algorithms often require lengthy and frequent algorithm training and lack reliability when the external loading or arm posture changes. This is partly because EMG PR is data-driven and does not account for the behavior of the underlying neural or biomechanical system from which the EMG signals are sourced. The objective of this project is to develop a novel EMG control of multifunctional transradial (TR) prostheses based on a systematic study of neuromuscular control and biomechanical roles of residual muscles in TR amputees. This research can potentially enhance the health, function, and quality of life of upper limb amputees. This project's concept, methods, and frameworks for enhancing EMG-based prosthesis control may be extended to other assistive robotics to benefit other patient populations such as stroke survivors. This project will impact STEM education by promoting project-based cross-training among K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students in underrepresented groups including females, minorities, and students with disabilities. The research may also impact the neuroscience and movement science communities by elucidating the control mechanism of the arm/hand and unveiling new knowledge of neuroplasticity and the internal model in upper limb amputees.

At the core of the multifunctional prosthesis control is a musculoskeletal model of the missing limb that will be used to interpret intended joint motions from EMG signals. The intellectual merit of this project includes a new concept for the control of robotic, multifunctional prosthetic arms/hands. The PIs' musculoskeletal model-based interface is fundamentally different from existing data-driven, EMG PR-based control because it interprets EMG signals and decodes user movement intent in a more biological way. Additionally, this effort will result in new knowledge regarding the neuroplasticity, neuromuscular control, and perceived biomechanical roles of residual muscles in upper limb amputees, which has not been systematically investigated based on the investigators' knowledge. Ultimately, the project will result in a new prosthesis control that, compared to state-of-the-art EMG PR-based control, may require significantly fewer and shorter calibrations, provide more intuitive, robust control (against posture changes, external loading, etc.), and enable multi-joint coordinated prosthesis operations. The investigators expect that the research may transform the way in which upper limb amputees operate multifunctional prostheses in daily life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NRI project, we proposed a novel concept for decoding electromyographic (EMG) signals recorded from the residual muscles of individuals with upper limb amputations for neural control of prosthetic arms. At the center of this concept was an EMG-driven musculoskeletal model that incorporates the known knowledge regarding the biological process for arm motion production into an EMG decoding algorithm, which was different from the state-of-the-art machine learning approaches. 

 

The intellectual merit of this project includes the following aspects: (1) A novel EMG-driven musculoskeletal model was developed that can map EMG signals into continuous, coordinated motion of hand and wrist. (2) By including the biomimicry model into the EMG decoding algorithm, our developed musculoskeletal model-based EMG decoder was inherently reliable and robust across arm postures, external loading conditions, and even human users. Therefore, a multi-user EMG decoder was also created and evaluated. This work was featured by many websites and media outlets, including NSF Science 360. The original story can be found at https://news.ncsu.edu/2018/05/generic-model-prosthetic-2018/. (3) Sequential, Adaptive Function Estimation (SAFE) was developed for determining the optimal EMG electrode placement on the residual limb of individuals with below-elbow amputations. This algorithm was critical for the clinical implementation of our proposed EMG prosthesis control because it was challenging to identify muscles in the residual limb due to the limb amputation surgery. (4) New knowledge regarding the advantages and disadvantages of machine-learning-based EMG decoder (the state-of-the-art approach) and physiological model-based method (our new method) were acquired in this project. This knowledge will motivate the field to explore hybrid approaches for neural control of prosthetic arms. These significant research outcomes have been summarized in eight published peer-reviewed journal papers, three additional journal manuscripts (under review), and four peer-reviewed conference articles. 

 

The broader impacts of this NRI award are extensive since the technology developed improves the function and usability of prosthetic arms, which, in turn, can further increase the function usage of impaired limbs and reduce disability in individuals with upper limb amputations. We have disseminated our research to not only the research communities in neural engineering, statistics, and biomechanics, but also the clinicians, prosthetists, individuals with limb amputations, and the general public. Also, through our education and K-12 outreach efforts, we trained many graduate and undergraduate students in Biomedical and Electrical Engineering and Statistics and promoted STEM to hundreds of K-12 students, including underrepresented groups. One involved student successfully finished his Ph.D. training and two team members became tenure-track professors. Finally, our technology developed in this NRI award has drawn attention from the prosthetics industry. We look forward to collaborating with the prosthesis companies to translate our technology to individuals with upper limb amputations in the future.
